ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about forces on the nano scale. It was interesting to learn about different applications. I also learned how to give an effective presentation
Learned a lot about forces on the nanoscale and how particles interact with each other at such a small scale.
Some physics

Basic ideas of universal force law. 
The different kinds of forces that act on varying scales and are responsible for different phenomenon observed. 
Quantification of forces

This course was a great experience and I am glad I have taken it. Although I already knew/heard of most, if not all, the topics discussed in this class, I had many missing perceptions, links, or knowledge gaps that this course has offered. I now have a better perception of abstract ideas in science and a better grasp of the different topics pertaining to forces. I would now speak more confidently about forces to a colleague or even in my research.

Also, the "talk" element of the course was a nice addition. Giving a technical presentation in a field that the audience is not fully familiar with is a challenging task. I had the opportunity to tackle this challenge through the end-of-semester talk, and the feedback on this was constructive.
I learned about how intermolecular forces are derived and how this relates to their relative strengths.
How forces at small scale can govern many interactions in the world.

I learned a variety of aspects of forces on a smaller scale. This includes what drives the fundamental forces of nature, chemical bonds, and dipole interactions. Also gained insight into membranes and at the end of the course, got to see the real-life applications of the material we studied. Lastly, gained valuable insight in how to give a talk or presentation at the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish we had more time in lecture to cover the topics. We covered so many different topics I got lost.

Homework could be better tied to lecture material. Moreover, the timing of the office hours and the homework due date was very poor, especially considering that the professor said that the office hours were necessary to complete the homework.
It's good that all concepts were explained in detailed
Could have covered a little bit more of surface

One of the strengths of this course is that it started with a very abstract basis and tried to build the momentum for more involved ideas later on. This gave a good grasp of concepts and where did they originate from, even though this was neatly done without the involvement of heavy math, which many students would appreciate.

Also, the history flavor that is weaved within the lectures and notes beautifies the delivery of the course. It is not always about the ideas in science, but also the scientists that were behind these discoveries, and the professor does a great job at this.
I don't think homework should require an extra TA session to be explained, of course the TA sessions were helpful but the homeworks were just too far from the lecture content.
It was really engaging and enjoyable! I think that talking about the applications and connections to the real world are fun.

Strengths of this course include the handouts which are very helpful and the fact that everything is compiled into a neat document makes it easier to understand and review. The course is very nicely structured and most material is presented on the board which keeps me engaged. Another strength is the amount of math presented and the approach to the material. Even though we were working with some math, it never got overwhelming and was kept simple so the emphasis could be placed on the concepts with only the required math being presented to understand them. Another strength of this course is the manageable workload.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. While I did learn some things, the assessments did not reinforce class learning and were too difficult for any real knowledge to be gleaned.
Nice professor and intriguing course materials
Yes. It facilitates the understanding of pathway through which different objects can interact, which is extremely helpful for students in the experimental science field.
Indeed.
Yes, this is a great elective!

I would recommend this course to another undergraduate student looking for an engineering elective. This is close to what my ideal engineering elective would be like where the focus is largely on the content and its applications instead of a lot of derivations. It helps someone who may not have as much experience or in depth knowledge in some of these areas understand them and the content can be applied to many different things in the real-world, for example, how microwaves heat food but not the plate.
